case_vignette: An 8-year-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of a progressively worsening nail dystrophy that began a few months ago! The patient’s mother denies a family history of skin diseases and reports that her son has no history of medical problems! On physical examination, all of the boy’s fingernails and toenails show hyperkeratosis, longitudinal ridging, loss of luster, and roughness! His hair, skin, and oral mucosa are unremarkable! Nail biopsy reveals spongiotic changes and exocytosis of inflammatory cells into the nail epithelia! The results of a fungal culture are negative!
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having issues with all my nails; they've gotten rough, lost their shine, and developed some ridges and thickening.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been experiencing these symptoms for a few months now.
Have you noticed any changes in color or separation of your nails from the nail bed?
No, I haven't noticed any changes in color or separation of my nails from the nail bed.
Do you have any other skin symptoms or conditions elsewhere on your body?
No, my hair, skin, and oral mucosa are all normal.
Do these nail changes affect all your fingernails and toenails?
Yes, all of my fingernails and toenails are affected.
Do you have any pain associated with your nails or have any difficulty in performing tasks?
No, I don't have any pain or difficulty performing tasks with my nails.
Do you have a history of psoriasis or any other skin conditions either personally or in your family?
No, I don't have a history of psoriasis or any other skin conditions, and there's no family history of skin diseases either.
Have you been diagnosed with any chronic diseases like diabetes or thyroid disorders, or are you taking any medications?
No, I have no history of medical problems and I am not taking any medications.
Final Diagnosis: Onychorrhexis

The patient also reports no history of medical problems and is not taking any medications.
